alfredsnippet.snippet:
The Ability to Trust Yourself When All Men Doubt You is One of the Prerequisites of True Manhood

Fabulous Science Fact and Fiction in the History of Scientific Discovery
John Waller
(p162)

"The suggestion of a prolonged period of suffering for the sake of an idea connotes a selfless commitment to the Truth. And an ability to bear the slings and arrows of anonymity and constant repudiation proves that the individual has the requisite mettle to enter the Pantheon of Heroes. Kipling fittingly identifies the ability to ‘trust yourself when all men doubt you’, as one of the prerequisites of true manhood."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - True Manhood
